BE11:15am

This evening the Fed is widely expected to lift the Fed funds rate corridor by 25bp to 1.25-1.5% - it would be the fifth hike since the onset of normalisation. For the last time Fed chair Yellen will hold a press conference. While likely striking a cautiously optimistic tone she may offer little in the direction of future guidance in order not to unduly restrain her successor’s flexibility. The Fed will also present new staff projections which could see not only a lower unemployment rate, but also a lower inflation rate. Even so, we think the Fed will stick to its projection of three more hikes in 2018. Over the past months markets have come closer to fully pricing in two Fed hikes for the next year with the FF Jan18 – FF Jan19 spread at 49bp coming from 15bp at the start of September.

Mouselet a sick man can make in a morning mistakes that it takes his healthy self three weeks to untangle

BE11:15am

And Citi's Morning Call.

red @Mouselet millions put to work often on nothing more than which side beer mat lands on...still happens
BE11:16am

The median “dots” are likely to stay put even as growth forecasts are revised up and unemployment forecasts revised down. It is probably too early for Fed officials to include fiscal stimulus in their projections.

Our economists expect Chair Yellen to emphasize the medium-term outlook for firmer inflation and continued rate hikes, and downplay the flatness of the curve.

On the strategy side, we suspect the front end could see a small rally because the credibility of commitments to 2018 hikes will be tepid especially under a new Fed Chair and because short positioning at the front end is sizeable.

Swedes Forester, thanks for that re moderately hopeful against your better judgment?

New joiner Quarles if anything may be more hawkish than Fischer based on public comments but it seems unlikely two more “three hikers” from September would want to shift to four hikes in 2018

UK Traction Shining Through — UK revenues increased +118% to £39.9m (Citi: £38.7m) highlighting the momentum in the businesses. Adjusted EBITDA for the period was £4.7m (Citi: £7.6m), with the leverage impacted by the previously flagged increase in marketing costs as well as a substantial increase in administrative costs as the business invests in business infrastructure. Average income per instruction increased +14% to £1,138 led by ancillary service revenues. LPE numbers increased +107% to 650 at 12 December. The company has guided up to £13m marketing and sales spend in the 2H18e.

Once again, we find that Purplebricks continues to
speak in riddles - 'we sold and completed £4.6bn of property with a further £3.8bn in the pipeline'. However, we cannot tell how many homes that equates to. And that is the one thing we think potential customers should be asking: 'If I pay you more than £1,000 what are the chances that you sell my home and how close will you get to the asking price?'

fjp73 Regulators, see the Buzz Feed article, on FBME? https://www.buzzfeed.com/tomwarren/secrets-of-one-of-the-worlds-dirtiest-banks-revealed. I rate Tom Warren, Briiliant article, I wonder what about FBME's associated companies.
BE11:33am

Our first read of the results is that the Group is spending more of its customers' money on marketing, but does it need to? According to the results release, 'Purplebricks has industry leading spontaneous brand awareness', which has grown to 37%, 17% above that of Rightmove, from people looking to sell their property. Does one need 17% more brand awareness than Rightmove?

At 397p, Puplebricks trades on a CY2018e PER of 106.2x against the sector (excluding Purplebricks), which trades on 13.6x and an EV/EBITDA of 75.4x (sector 8.7x).
Risks. In our view, Purplebricks is currently priced for perfection, yet we believe this early stage disruptor has yet to prove the efficacy of its business model. Should the model stumble, the share price may do likewise. Upside risks to our thesis include higher growth in fees, instructions and LPEs than we assume.

Today's statement guides to a full year Pre Tax Profit range of £360-£400m. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently expecting the group to report Headline Pre Tax Profits of £375m in FY 2017/18, so we would not expect much change in consensus today. We believe, however, that the risk remains firmly to the downside. Having reported £61m of PTP in FY H1, the group will need to deliver an FY H2 profit of around £315m. Last year Dixons Carphone made an FY H2 profit of £352m, so this implies a profit decline of just £37m in FY H2 (versus the £83m decline reported today for FY H1).

Investment view: Outperform, 215p price target
Dixons Carphone has a very strong market position in both the UK and Northern Europe, and we think its business is likely to prove more resilient
than the market expects given share gains in electricals and its Nordic exposure. DC should also benefit from further cost savings in the UK (e.g.,
lower rents) and from new warehousing in the Nordic area.
We think valuation is attractive, DC has material international exposure (c.30% of profit) and it is gaining share in electricals, but it faces further
mobile headwinds short term which means EPS visibility is low. Our DCF suggests an implied share price of 215p, while a sum-of-parts produces a
range of 170-250p per share. DC is trading at 6x CY18 P/E and offers a dividend yield of approaching 7%.

This was not an upbeat statement and 2019 consensus should come down, but much of this is known and the shares are -18% since end Oct. 2017/18 profit guidance looks OK, but 2019 is weaker, a weak pipeline is expected (but known) and the MT growth targets look less likely and the margin more dependent on cost cutting. Profit for 2017 is expected to be at the top end of the previous trading profit guidance range of £65-70m vs MS £71.1m. For 2018 it expects c. £80m vs MSe £82.6m (consensus is £81-82m), but we have £3.8m from its healthcare acquisition and guidance excludes this. It then expects another year of “good growth” in 2019 vs MSe £89.3m (consensus is c£100, but is a bit stale we
think) with growth after that dependent on demand reverting to trend. The LT targets of 5-7% mkt growth and 5-6% margins had caveats (costs, OCPs and mkt growth) and it is flagging weaker growth in some mkts (ie UK) and having more of a focus on lowering costs. 2017 ND is expected at the bottom of range of £150-200m (pre-M&A, which settles in Q1 2018) and £195m (ex M&A we are at £179m) and revenue is expected to be “just under” £3bn vs MS £3.03bn and compares to guidance of £3.1bn (FX and timing impacting this). Order intake at £3bn is good, but known and the pipeline is expected to be noticeably lower at £4-5bn

BE11:52am

Serco's budgeting process suggests FY18e EBITA of £80m i.e. c14% growth y/y. This is despite revenue which Serco expects to be flat: the outlook therefore implies margins could rise from 2.37% in FY17e to 2.75% in FY18e. Further transformational savings in FY19e should drive 'further good' profit growth, but from FY20e Serco may require new wins to sustain profit improvement. The long-term targets of 5-7% growth p.a. and 5-6% margins remain intact, but the market environment will need to improve before they can get there. We regard the current environment as a trough, but timing on any improvement is highly uncertain.
